story: Our fathers have a saying: “where there is determination there is a way.” This is a story about two young girls, Farida and Rehema who were determined to find their way, no matter how hard their lives were. Farida and Rehema are orphans. Rehema is not well-behaved, while Farida is the complete opposite. One day they went to school and the teacher asked them, “Why do you guys come to school only once or twice a week? Who takes care of you at home?” Rehema replied, “What will you do about it after I tell you?” Farida warned her sister that was not the right way to talk to others. Farida explained to the teacher that they used to live on the street until their Grandma adopted them. They live a hard life because Grandma doesn’t take good care of them and makes them cook, do all the chores, and clean the house. Grandma made money by cleaning other people’s houses in the town, but now she makes Rehema and Farida clean the houses. They don’t have time to study when they return home. They are always hungry because Grandma doesn’t give them much to eat. “Both our mom and our dad died,” Farida said to the teacher. “I am really sorry, Farida,” the teacher said. “No problem.”, she replied. Rehema was not very happy with her sister for telling the teacher about what was going on in their family. “Do you think she is going to help you?” she yelled at Farida “She is just curious. That’s all. Is that bad? What else can be worse?” Farida asked. “But do you honestly think she will help you?” Rehema replied, her face wrinkled with anger. Rehema was almost 14 and seemed to be angry about everything around her. Farida sat down for a moment and thought about her life and that of her little sister, Rehema. “But do you honestly think she will help you?” Rehema replied, her face wrinkled with anger. Rehema was almost 14 and seemed to be angry about everything around her. Farida sat down for a moment and thought about her life and that of her little sister, Rehema. Right after they finished cooking, Grandma’s daughter Mwanahamisi, whom they called auntie, came to visit. When auntie came and saw the lunch Rehema and Farida made, she ate their lunch and then told them to go clean her house as well. Auntie’s house was so filthy that it was midnight before they finished cleaning. They were so hungry and so tired that they fell asleep at auntie’s house. The next day, Farida and Rehema sent out on their way back to their Grandma’s. When auntie found out they had left, she felt relieved, because she did not want to give them any food at her house. On the way back to Grandma’s house, Rehema and Farida met a young man named Issa. He seemed to be lost and looking for directions. “Jambo! Ladies. Which way to Newalla town?” Issa asked. “Oh. We just came from there. We came from our auntie’s and we are going to our Grandma’s. Newalla is that way,” said Farida pointing toward the town. “Asante sana. Excuse me, but you girls look very tired already. It’s only 10AM,” Issa said to them. “We worked all night last night and haven’t eaten a thing since the dinner the day before yesterday.” Farida replied. “Oh no! Come here and I will give you some food. I have some left- overs from my breakfast I picked up on the way to this village,” Issa told them and got a bag from his car. “Wow! Asante sana, but we don’t want to trouble you, sir” Farida replied. “But we will take it if it is not too much trouble,” Rehema replied. With a smile on his face, Issa gave them some food. Rehema and Farida were so hungry they devoured the left-over food in a matter of seconds. “How many schools are there in this area?” Issa asked them. “Here? There is only one small primary school which we attend,” Farida replied. Issa asked them all to sit down, because he wanted to talk to them. They found out that Issa is from Dar es Salaam, and he was visiting the region because he was going to become the director of a new woodcraft manufacturing factory. After hearing the life stories of Rehema and Farida, Issa suggested that they live with him starting next month. Issa was also an orphan and he studied hard to change his life. Issa knew that education is the only thing that can change one’s life. Because of all his personal experiences as an orphan, Issa saw Rehema and Farida as his sisters, because he knew how hard it is to live as orphans and live with other families, and do other people’s chores for them. “I would like you to become part of my family” he said. The girls were thrilled to hear it, and happily followed Issa to his new home in Newalla. When they arrived, Issa told them to make themselves at home. As they looked around the house, they saw things they had not seen before things like electricity, a television, and a computer with internet access. Issa was a very young man, but became quickly successful by studying hard and getting a college education. He received his bachelor’s degree in business administration from a university in Dar es Salaam and also a full scholarship to a university overseas where he earned a master’s degree in business administration. Is sa was single, so he enjoyed having sisters around so they could live as a family. Issa had a maid and a cook, so Rehema and Farida didn’t have to cook or do any chores. The girls were happy to have time to study. They attended school every day and worked really hard. They read as many books as they could find and learned to speak English as well. Thanks to Issa’s kindness, the girls grew up and went to college. They studied even harder in college and received scholarships which waived their tuition and fees for books. After graduating college, they got jobs; Farida worked at the Bank of Tanzania and Rehema became the head of a secondary school. They lived happy lives and became great role models for all the orphans in the rion.

story: Kiokote lived with his family in Mangaka village near River Ruvuma, where he liked to fish. He had a small boat and a very good fishing net. He also had more than goats and plenty of food. There was no one in the village that was better at fishing than he was. Also, nobody made goatskin leather clothes and accessories better than him. Because he always wore a goatskin jacket he proudly made, he was also known as a goat jacket man. However, no one in Mangaka village liked Kiokote, because he was very selfish. One day Likoti, who was another fisherman in the village, went to Kiokote’s home for help. Likoti was sick and could not fish, so he and his family didn’t have any food. “How is your afternoon, Kiokote?” Likoti asked. “Good Likoti, and you?” he responded. “I have not been doing very well. I have been ill and my family doesn’t have any food because Ihaven’t been to the river for the past three days.” “So how do you want me to help you?” Kiokote asked. “I could use two small fish, some goat milk, and some money for my medication,” said Likoti. “I cannot give you any of my food or money because your illness and your problems do not concern me,” said Kiokote. Likoti headed back to his home, saddened by his failure to get the help he needed. The next day at dawn, Kiokote took his fishing net and his boat and headed to the river for another fishing day. When he got to the river bank, there was a boy named Elimu sitting there, looking out at the river. Elimu’s father was Darweshi, and they lived very close to where Kiokote lived. As soon as Elimu saw Kiokote coming, Elimu asked him, “Are you going out to fish? If so, could you look for my father? He hasn’t come home for two days.” Hearing this, Kiokote replied, “Really? I will see if I can find your dad. Can you go to my home and feed my goats some weeds? Be sure to feed the little ones first.” “Yes sir. I will be sure to do it, but please, please find my dad and come home with him,” replied Elimu with wet eyes and a sob in his voice. When Kiokote got in his boat and went downstream, he was surprised to find other fishermen fishing there. They seemed to be doing quite well. He then rowed to the deeper part of the river. He lowered his net into the deep water and trapped some fish, but they were too small so Kiokote threw them back. He lowered his net at another spot where he thought large fish were swimming and soon there were plenty of fish trapped in the net. When the other fishermen saw that he had caught a lot of fish, they offered to help, but as expected Kiokote didn’t think he needed anyone’s help. He could do it all by himself, and he certainly didn’t want to share any of the big fish he was catching. After the other fishermen had gone, Kiokote was left all alone to try to pull up the net. The net was very heavy, but he kept pulling on it with all his might. Still, he wasn’t strong enough to pull the net up. Instead, the big fish were pulling the net further into the water. Kiokote fought hard with the fish in his net, but suddenly, his boat capsized and he was pulled into the water. While all this was happening, Elimu went to Kiokote’s home to feed weeds to his goats. When he arrived at Kiokote’s home, he heard screaming from the house. Elimu rushed into Kiokote’s house and found Kiokote’s wife Fatuma lying on the ground in agony. Elimu asked Fatuma, “What’s wrong? What happened?” “Go find Gaudiosa. Tell her to come to me now. Something is wrong. My baby is not due to come out this month. It’s too early. Go get Gaudiosa!” Fatuma screamed. Elimu ran out to look for Gaudiosa, an elderly lady who serves as a midwife in the village. Elimu ran to Gaudiosa’s house, but she was not there. Elimu ran around the whole village, but he couldn’t find Gaudiosa. After searching for her for 20 minutes door to door, he decided to run to a clinic in the town nearby. It’s about 20 minutes by motorcycle, but Elimu thought that he had no other choice. He had to go find a doctor in the town. Elimu ran like a rabbit on a muddy, narrow road. He jumped over little ponds along the way. He sweated, and his clothes were all muddy, but he ran and ran as fast as he could. By the time he got close to the town, he realized that his right was foot bleeding. A broken bottle piece had pierced his bare foot, but that didn’t stop him. He kept running to the clinic. When Elimu got to the clinic, he almost fell down from the pain. “Oh my gosh, are you alright? What happened?” a nurse at the clinic asked Elimu. The nurse was looking at Elimu’s bleeding food. A doctor who was diagnosing a patient inside a partitioned area looked out and saw Elimu catching his breath. “Was there an accident, boy?” doctor asked. “What happened to your leg?” “No, no. I am fine, doctor, but please come with me quickly. A mother in Mangaka village is about to give birth and she is all alone and she is in trouble. Please come!” “We need to take a look at your leg first. You are bleeding. You will be in big trouble if we don’t stop your bleeding,” the doctor said while he examined Elimu’s foot. Meanwhile, Kiokote was in the river struggling to get on top of his capsized boat. He lost almost all of his strength from fighting with his net, which was now lost along with all the big fish. He now had to struggle to keep from drowning. It was so difficult for Kiokote to get on top of the boat because the surface of the boat was so slippery and he kept on falling back into the water. I am the wealthiest person in the whole village, but now I have nothing to show for it and I am losing my life as well. My wife is about to give birth next month and I even have 10 goats. Why have I been so selfish in my life? Why haven’t Ishared with the needy? Why didn’t I share fish with my friends? Oh no… I am so silly…” Kiokote thought as he was losing his last bit of strength to get on the capsized boat. “ Hey! What happened? Do you need help over there?” a man shouted to Kiokote from a distance. It was Elimu’s father Darweshi. He discovered Kiokote as he was returning home from fishing a long way downstream. Kiokote couldn’t even say a word because he was so thankful to see Darweshi approaching him to help. He shed tears from his eyes and thanked God for sending a lifesaver. He decided to be a good man from that moment on. Darweshi pulled Kiokote out of the water and returned home with a lot of fish he had caught from downstream. “Oh you guys are home! You have no idea about what happened while you guys were gone!” said Zulfa, the nurse from the clinic. This little boy ran all the way to the clinic to help for this lady to deliver her premature boy. Luckily, God was with us this afternoon. She delivered the boy successfully. Elimu limped and hugged his dad who was helping Kiokote sit down on a chair in front of the house. “What happened to your leg, my son?” Darweshi asked Elimu. “Oh that. You wouldn’t believe what he did today. He is a hero today!” said Zulfa. Zulfa explained to Kiokote and Darweshi how Elimu injuered his foot running to the clinic. “He refused to get his leg treated until we came to the village to help Kiokote’s wife.” When Kiokote heard all this, he shed more tears and hugged Elimu. “You are my son. You saved my wife and my son. Thank you, Elimu. Your dad saved me today, Thank you Darweshi. Thank you everyone. Thank you, God,” said Kiokote still shedding tears Kiokote told everyone, “Self-centeredness is really foolishness. I was self-centeredness at times when I should have worked with others”. Next day, Kiokote took two goats in his hands and gave them to Derweshi. “Thank you very much for your help, my friend,” Kiokote said. Kiokote also went to Likoti’s house to give him a big wheel of goat cheese he made and also two fresh buckets of goat milk and said, “I promise to change my selfish ways and start working with you as a team in everything.” His friends forgave him and they went on being good friends, helping each other through good times and hard times. Everyone shared and everyone helped each other. The whole village was full of sharing and helping minds and abundant happiness.

story: Ashura is a kind and cute girl who lives in a small town called Majengo. She lives with her dad, who sells vegetables from his stand, and her mom, who cooks the most delicious Ugali (African rice cake made from maize). Ashura’s dad returns from his job each day looking tired. Even though he works hard, he worries about feeding the family and buying Ashura’s school supplies. Ashura feels sorry for her dad having to work so hard for the family, and she thanks him for his effort. She speaks to her dad after he comes back late one night from work. “Dad! My teacher says no matter how difficult a situation is, if we try hard without losing hope and remain honest, everything will turn out fine. So cheer up, Dad!” Her dad smiles faintly. Her mom nods with approval. However, things in Ashura’s home are getting worse. There are days when they have nothing to eat. Then one day, her dad decides to go far away to sell pineapples and cabbages. Ashura worries about her dad biking a long way, all alone, with a large basket of fruits and vegetables. “Goodbye, Dad. Good things will happen to us soon. Cheer up Papa. Cheer up!” “Okay, you must mind what your mother says.” He hugs Ashura and her mother and sets off on the long journey A few days pass, and Ashura does not hear anything from her dad. Ashura and her mother start worrying about him. Then one day, the village headman runs quickly to Ashura’s home. “Bad news!” he cries, “Your father had a terrible accident on the way back home!” Ashura’s mother sees everything go dark. “A speeding car hit your father and he is in the hospital,” the village headman explains. “He is still alive, but the driver left the scene and there is no one to pay the medical expenses.” Ashura and her mother rush to the hospital. “Dad! Dad!” When Ashura sees her sick father, her heart breaks. “Love ... how did this happen? ” Her mother starts weeping when she sees her husband. Her father also starts crying when he sees his wife and Ashura. Ashura wants to comfort her father and mother. “Mommy and Daddy, do not cry. We are good people, so good things will happen soon, as long as we don’t lose hope!” Suddenly, her dad is horribly angry at her and says “Ashura! Stop telling us everything will turn out fine. I was hit by a car, and you are still saying everything will be okay!” Ashura is distraught, but she stays with her father until he falls asleep. She then leaves the hospital to go to a big tree growing at the entrance to the village. She prays, “God, my father got hurt, and he is very sick. I just wanted to give him hope, but Imade him angry. What should I do?” “Hello kid!” she hears someone calling her. When she turns around, there is a man wearing a suit standing behind her. “I am not familiar with this town. Is there a hospital around here?” he asks. “Yes, there is a hospital. Follow me. I will take you there.” Ashura speaks to him on the way to the hospital. “You are wearing a nice suit. You also look smart and kind so can I ask you something?” He smiles at her and says, “What are you wondering? Let’s hear it.” Ashura asks him, “My teacher says that things are never as good or as bad as they seem. Even though bad things happen, if we don’t lose our hope and fight through it, everything will turn out fine. Is this true?” “Of course! It is up to you all along. No matter how difficult a situation is, if we try hard without losing hope and remain honest, everything will turn out fine. I grew up in a refugee shelter but Iam thankful for every day of my life. I never gave up and worked very hard, and so now I own a company. If I felt bitter about my poor situation in the refugee shelter and never tried, I would never have been able to achieve my dream and own my company,” he answers. They are still talking when they arrive at the hospital. “So if I don’t lose hope, everything will turn out fine, right? Ah! What a relief. Thank you very much for talking with me. Here we are. This is the hospital. My father is here in the first room.” Ashura looks through the window at her father. The man in the suit turns to look and sees Ashura’s father. There is a surprised look on his face and he suddenly runs to the bathroom. Ashura looks at him and thinks, “He is a nice person. I hope he is not here because something bad has happened…” The man in the suit, Aron, runs to the bathroom and locks the door. “How could I have caused this terrible car accident? Ashura is a kind-hearted girl and I hit her father and ran away.” He punches the wall with one hand and cries while clamping his mouth with the other. He feels very regretful. Aron is a businessman who trades nuts. A few days ago, he was on the way to sign a contract and got lost on an unfamiliar street. He hit a person with his car and unwittingly fled because he was so scared. After the accident, Aron could not eat and sleep. He was overwhelmed by his guilt and returned to the scene of the crime. He decides that he would go and apologize for his mistake. However, he is very scared and cannot bring himself to leave the bathroom. After one hour, he hears someone knocking on his door and comes back to reality. It is still difficult for him to face Ashura’s father. Then he remembers Ashura’s clear eyes when he met her at the entrance to the village. He finally finds the heart to tell the truth and walks to the room where Ashura’s father is recovering. He confesses his mistakes and asks for forgiveness. “I am sincerely sorry for everything. I will do everything to help you recover and start working again. Don’t worry about the medical expenses. Once you get out of the hospital, I will open a store in the city. Also, if you allow me, Iwould love to pay Ashura’s school fees until she finishes her college degree. I know it is not enough to ask for forgiveness, but I will try my best. I am truly sorry, please forgive me.” Aron looks at Ashura’s father kneeling down and asking for forgiveness. Ashura starts to cry. The family forgives Aron. After six months, her father and mother open a clothing boutique. Aron comes every weekend to make suits with his friends. He also never forgets to bring fairytale books and candy for Ashura. Tomorrow, Ashura will start her studies at a great school that has the best dormitory in Tanzania. Aron bought a red school bag and English dictionary for her. Ashura promises that she will study very hard and will become an inspiration to all children in Tanzania. Most of all, she will never lose hope.

story: Once upon a time, there was a small village. Many of the people in the village were very poor. One of the men in the village was named Mr. Mshamu. Mr. Mshamu had three children: Hamiss, Hadija, and Karim. Their family was very poor and they had no car and no farm. Mr. Mshamu knew that education was very important, so he worked hard to send his kids to school. He hoped that one day, his kids would get good jobs to help bring their family out of poverty. But Hadija got married young and could not continue (his/her) education. Hamiss did not work hard in school and ended up on the streets. Mr. Mshamu’s last hope was Karim. Mr. Mshamu gave Karim lots of support and made sure that he worked hard in school so that he could go to college one day and help his family. Karim was a very kind and intelligent child and his teachers loved him. As time went on, Karim made two new friends: Hassan and Yasa. Hassan and Yasa were the sons of the village leader and were very rich and spoiled, but they bought Karim nice things. Hassan and Yasa were a bad influence on Karim. He started to skip classes and lie to his parents. Mr. Mshamu and Karim’s teachers were very disappointed in him. They tried to help him become a good boy again, but Karim kept getting into trouble. Karim became so much trouble that he was expelled from school. Mr. Mshamu was heartbroken over the failure of his last child. Life became harder for the Mshamu family and they had less money. They could not take care of Karim anymore, so he ended up on the street like his brother, Hamiss. Karim had turned into a monster. He caused so much trouble that even Hassan and Yasa did not want to be near him. Karim bullied kids and took their money. With each bad thing Karim did, his face changed. Every time he saw his reflection, he looked scarier and scarier. Karim became so worried about his appearance that he went home one day to ask his parents for help. “Did I do something wrong?” he asked his parents. “Think about your actions, Karim. Do you think you did something wrong?” they replied. Karim sat down and thought about all of the bad things he had done. He felt guilty and sad about all of the pain he had caused people. When he looked in the mirror in his house, he was shocked by what he saw. In the mirror was the scariest and ugliest monster he had ever seen. He began to cry and immediately regretted all of the bad things he had done. He had let down his parents, his teachers, and his friends. He began to pray to God for mercy. Karim decided that he needed to apologize to everyone he had hurt. He apologized to the kids he had bullied and they gladly accepted his apology. Then something strange happened. His appearance started to go back to normal. He apologized to his teachers and his appearance changed even more. And finally, he apologized to his parents. “I am so sorry for all of the pain I have caused you. Will you please forgive me?” he asked. “Of course, Karim. We are so proud that you have learned your lesson. We love you,” his parents answered.’ “Thank you for your love,” said Karim, smiling. Karim’s face went completely back to normal. In fact, it shined as bright as the sun. Ever since, Karim has been kind and giving. He now has a very bright future ahead of him.

story: Most people in Tanzania have not heard of Ifakara. It was its own hidden, isolated world and it was also my home. Most of the people who are born in Ifakara never leave, but I was one of the exceptions. I have four siblings: an older sister, and older brother, and two younger sisters. As a child, Ilonged to go to school and I finally persuaded my parents to let me go. And so, I started school when I was six years old. The minimum school starting age in Tanzania at the time was seven for standard one, but my teachers let me in anyway because I was such an eager student. I enjoyed learning very much. Iknew that if I wanted to go as far with my education as possible, I would need to learn about the world beyond Ifakara. Luckily, I had a special window to the outside world. There was a television mounted in a street café near my house where I met countless new characters. I especially loved a character named Dexter from a show called Dexter’s Laboratory. He was interested in nature, science, and design, and he was the smallest in his class. He was also not the most popular kid in school, so I could relate to him. Dexter taught me about how science can be used to solve problems and I knew I wanted to be like him when I grew up. Because of my outstanding performance in school and unanimous recommendations from all of my teachers, after standard four Iwas selected to attend a boarding school with a full scholarship. My new school was much more interesting and challenging than my old school. I was finally able to take science classes in secondary school, just like Dexter. I had fallen in love with science. I started reading books and any materials Icould find related to science. I read about topics such as quantum physics and astrophysics that even my teachers could not explain to me. My final year of secondary school, I pursued my first science and engineering project on sustainable alternative energy sources. I had learned about global warming in a science magazine and came up with a biogas project. In Ifakara, most households use firewood and charcoal as primary fuel, but these sources are very cumbersome and far from ecologically sustainable. However, many people in Ifakara are animal herders and I had the idea to use the manure from the cows as a biogas energy source because there was so much of it and it would never run out. I then spent my last quarter of secondary school learning about how to break down the manure to harness the methane gas for energy. Since I didn’t have access to the Internet, I spent most of my time reading in the library to find everything I could on the subject. When I graduated secondary school, I spent all of my time working on my project. Iperformed many experiments and finally came up with a final idea for a model. My only problem was that I didn’t have the money to make it happen and I couldn’t get more money from my sponsors. I started writing letters to people to help me pay for my project. I even dared to apply to universities abroad to further my education. Finally, after two years of hard work, I received a response from Stanford University, one of the best universities in the United States. Stanford was an amazing place. Before coming to Stanford, I thought Dexter was the only other curious person in the whole world. On the contrary, I found more people like Dexter at Stanford. These people, who are now my friends, are also interested in science and enjoy finding solutions to problems. My first year at Stanford, I made a friend named Hari and we worked together to create tools for efficient, cost-effective diagnosis of Malaria. My second year, I made another friend named Runi and we are studying HIV. I have learned that the one thing better than being a Dexter is finding other Dexters to work with. I still have a long way to go before I discover or invent something new, but I know that one day, with hard work, I can create something that will be useful to my country. However, I know one thing: I have become the Dexter that I have always wanted to be. And as long as I don’t give up, I know that I can help change the world.

story: Once, in a village in India called Chandra Babu Nagar, there lived a girl named Sasikala. She lived with her parents and two older brothers. They were very poor. They had difficulty finding money and had to work really hard. Sasikala’s family lived right next to a cheese making farm. Sasikala’s mother had a friend who worked there and she gave Sasikala’s family the crumbs that were left over from making the cheese. The family appreciated this very much because they all enjoyed the cheese from the dairy farm even the cheese that was a little old. Sasikala’s father loved the cheese the most. But Sasikala had one major problem: her father’s anger. Her father would go to the bar and drink. Sometimes, he came home drunk and did not realize what he was doing. He would be very threatening and mean to his children. Sasikala and her brothers were very frightened of him. At night, Sasikala’s father would ask for more beers. Sasikala rushed to get the drinks before her father beat Sasikala’s mother. Sasikala’s father always yelled at his wife for no reason. Sasikala and her brothers always watched him in silence, too afraid to even whisper. Their mother would have to go to a friend’s house to escape from their father. Sasikala’s father wasn’t angry all the time. He would switch back and forth between being angry and calm for no apparent reason. Sasikala and her brothers began to investigate the causes of their father’s angry moods. After school, they walked barefoot all the way to a big internet café in the town of Kuduru. They didn’t know how to use computers. They didn’t even know any English, but they desperately wanted to help their father. They used a dictionary to translate websites. They read lots of medical articles and searched and searched to find the cause of their father’s symptoms. After spending an entire month reading and searching both day and night, they still didn’t have an answer for their father’s behavior. Sasikala’s brothers lost hope and stopped searching. They told Sasikala, “It’s just the way father is, and we have to accept it and live with it until we die.” But Sasikala, after reading and learning all those new things, still believed that her father’s mood swings were because of a health issue. Sasikala was sitting at the internet café one day and feeling very sad because she still hadn’t found out what was causing her father’s symptoms. She was about to start crying in front of the computer when she came across an article about eating habits and health. She started to read. The author recommended recording what a patient eats and how it affects their mood. Sasikala went back home with lots of hope. She monitored and jotted down everything her father ate. She took notes for two weeks and matched her notes to the times when her father was angry. Finally, she figured it out! She realized that whenever her father eats cheese he becomes angry and mad, then gets drunk and beats his family. It was a rainy afternoon, but Sasikala was so excited about her findings that she ran all the way to the internet café in the rain. She wanted to see if eating cheese and mood swings were indeed related. She got there a few minutes before it closed. Sasikala looked on a medical website to find the name of the sickness. She found it! She discovered that headaches and anger could be caused by Tyramine, a compound often found in old cheese. Sasikala was so happy that she ran all the way back home. When she got home it was late. She was shaking from the cold but deep inside she felt warm because of her great discovery. Her father scolded her because she was late. Sasikala tried to explain to her father, but he wouldn’t listen. Sasikala decided to do the experiment all by herself, because she loved her father so much. She convinced her mom not to get any cheese from their neighbors for two weeks. Her father was constantly complaining, “Why don’t we get cheese anymore?” Finally, Sasikala explained to her father what she was trying to do and he agreed to participate. After spending two weeks without eating any cheese or drinking old milk, Sasikala’s father did not have any Tyramine left in his body. story: In one African village called Masagna, there lived a young boy whose name was Suma. Suma was the only child and he lived with his parents. He was known for causing a lot of trouble and problems around the village, and because of his reckless behavior, he was expelled from his school. After being expelled, he did more thoughtless and rash actions with his free time without any sense of guilt. Suma often stole his father’s wallet and wasted his day by hanging out with his bad friends stealing from other people’s homes. His patient mother and father were very upset and were worried about his future. The villagers gathered together and started to bad mouth and criticize Suma. “I don’t understand how such a child like Suma was born from that kind and generous couple. It is truly a shame”, one man said in disbelief, shaking his head sideways. Suma’s parents prayed day and night in hopes that their child, Suma, would change and be a kind and a nice boy. Unfortunately, Suma never changed. The Masagna villagers pitied Suma’s parents. When they visit Suma’s mother to comfort her, she would face the ground and shed tears. One day, Suma was on a trip to a different village in a search to steal new goods. On his way, he spotted a girl from another village and Suma was instantly attracted to her beautiful looks. Suma followed the girl, and as the boy as he is, he believed that he would be able to make her his girlfriend. “Hey!”, Suma called the girl and walked towards her. The girl turned around to see who was calling her and saw a boy approaching. When Suma got near the girl, he introduced himself to her. “Hi. My name is Suma. I saw you walking down the road and I thought you would want some company on your way. What is your name?”, Suma said and asked enthusiastically. “Oh, hi. My name is Neema”, Neema said hesitatingly. “ Umm look, I am in a hurry right now so it would be best if I go alone. Thanks anyway and it was nice seeing you, Suma”, she said and started to walk away in a fast pace. Suma was surprised by Neema’s answer. He thought she was going to accept his offer and this made Suma a little upset. “What? Hey, hold on a second!”, Suma shouted and quickly grabbed her wrist. Neema suddenly felt a sharp pain on her left wrist, and felt uncomfortable with Suma’s behavior. “My mother is waiting for me on the other side of the village. I must go quickly. Please, could you let go of my arm?” Neema said with sternness. However, the selfish and self-centered Suma didn’t care what Neema said. Instead he steadied his gaze on her face with a playful look and grabbed her arm stronger. Evil thoughts started to fill his mind. “I understand, but I have something to say to you. Ineed you to follow me to my village” Suma said with a bit of harshness and pulled her arm to his direction. Neema understanding the dangerous situation quickly pulled her arm away and started crying and running away from Suma. Suma got extremely angry and started running to get her, reaching out his arms. A man called Hosea walking with his daughter, Hadassah, saw what was happening and knew that the girl was in trouble. Not going any further, Neema tripped on a rock and fell. She turned her head and saw Suma approaching and getting close to her. Suma was breathing heavily and was wearing a scary face. Neema being terrified started to scream out for help. “Help! Help! Please, anyone! Please, just help me!” Neema screamed. Hosea and Hadassah heard Neema’s scream and they both ran as fast as possible to her. The other villagers also heard Neema’s scream and quickly approached to where Neema was. Suma seeing the people approaching, he hurriedly fled the scene. When Hosea and his daughter reached the place, they assured Neema and assisted her to the hospital. It was a late night and Suma was captured by the villagers. He was sent to the police station and the people testified that Suma was a criminal that stole people’s valuable possessions and was attempting to commit sexual abuse on Neema. Suma was immediately sent to prison with other prisoners. Suma’s life in prison was miserable and terrifying. With no guard watching over them, the ruthless prisoners would beat up Suma and leave bruises and cuts on his body. The prisoners also stole his clothes and his food from him. Bomp! Bomp! Bo-. Suma held one of the prisoner’s fist. Suma’s face was covered in blood and bruises, and his lips were torn from the countless punches. “Please...stop. I would do anything. Please, just don’t kill me”, Suma pleaded to his cell mates. There were terror in his eyes, and Suma couldn’t endure the pain any longer. The prisoners laughed and one prisoner squeezed Suma’s face and forced Suma to look at him. “You filthy thing. If you want to live, I suggest you go crawl into that corner and never make a sound because if you do, I will make sure that you beg me to kill you instead”, the strongest prisoner said. The prisoner punched his face one last time and spat at him. The prisoner left and went back to their cells. Suma never experienced such horror in his life. On the other side, Suma’s parents were worried ill and didn’t know where their son was. Their son was missing for days and didn’t have one clue where Suma could be. “Honey, don’t worry too much. Suma will be back soon…”, Suma’s father said and quietly assured his wife. Suma’s parents were afraid that their only son left the village with his bad friends. The only thing they could do was to pray to God for their son’s safety and that Suma would come back home safe and alive. Suma was hiding in the corner in his cell and did not make any noise like he was instructed. He hasn’t had any food for days, and he truly started to believe that he was going to die in prison. ‘Am I going to die in here?’, Suma thought. ‘I have been stealing from other people and breaking my parent’s hearts. Neema was such a beautiful girl. Why did I hurt and scare her? What have I done. I am paying for my own sins, and I will continue to do so after I die when I go to hell. Will even God forgive me?’, Suma questioned himself and buried his face into his knees. Three weeks have passed, and Suma was released from prison. He was granted an early release without a trial because he was still a minor. Suma didn’t feel any relief after being released from prison. He felt ashamed for his crimes, and he had nowhere to go. “Who would accept a wretch like me…” Suma said quietly to himself. “I can’t even go back to my own parents...how can I? After what I have done to them and to the villagers. Someone like me shouldn’t even beg for forgiveness.”,thought Suma, roaming around the streets. Suma was walking down the street until he noticed a familiar face. It was Hosea, the man that helped Neema to the hospital three weeks ago. Suma immediately felt nervous and ashamed. He imagined the man grabbing him and sending him back to prison. “Suma”, the man called. Suma didn’t know whether he should look up or down. He was scared to face the eyes of the man. “Suma”, the man called again. “Let me see your face”. Suma slowly lifted his chin to face the man, preparing himself for the horror he will be facing. When he saw the man’s face, Suma twitched for a quick second. He didn’t look scary or have the mean eyes. The man’s eyes were gently bent downwards, making fine lines underneath his eyes. His brown lips pushing his cheekbones upwards. “Where are you heading?”, Hosea asked. Suma was silent. He didn’t have an answer to that question. He knew he should quickly answer because the man was waiting, but that man seemed to already know what his answer was. He still had that gentle smile on his face. “I...don’t know”, Suma said with a quiet voice. “Do you have a home? What about your parents?”, the man prompted. “My parents are home. But it is not a place for me to go back to.”, Suma answered. Hosea’s brows slightly shifted inwards. He didn’t understand Suma’s answer. “I have done terrible and unforgivable things. Things Ishould have not done. I can’t go back to my village and my home. How can I ask my parents for forgiveness after what I have done to them”, Suma said with grief. “Suma, listen”, the man said. “Your parents will forgive you. You are their loving son. Even if you have done regretful things in the past, the present is only important. Have some courage and go back to your parent’s arms. And when you go back, be a changed young man.” The man brought back the smile he wore when he first called Suma. It gave Suma the courage to answer. “I will.”, Suma said. Suma didn’t forget to return the smile. Suma has been wandering around the streets for a couple of days, filling himself with edible food he could find from the garbage. The confidence he had when he talked with Hosea seemed to have evaporated. Today, Suma was determined to go back home. He started walking towards his house. From a distance, Suma’s parents recognized their son. “Suma!”, his mother shouted. Suma’s mother and father ran toward their son, and held him very close to their hearts. Tears ran down through his mother’s cheeks. “Thank you, God! Thank you for protecting my son and bringing him back home safely”, Suma’s father quietly said embracing his family. Suma was no longer the reckless boy from the past. He was a changed boy like he promised Hosea. He was ashamed for all the trouble he caused to the villagers and his friends. “Mother and Father, I am very sorry for causing so much trouble. I was a son that only fought everyday and stole from our neighbor’s homes. I am truly sorry, please forgive me”, Suma said facing the ground. It didn’t take a second for Suma’s parents to immediately hold their son’s small shoulders with both their arms. They forgave their son entirely at once. From that day on, Suma was reborn. He was determined to study and go back to school again and he even helped his parents with house chores. Six months later, Suma went to Neema’s place to apologize to her and ask for forgiveness. Suma’s parents were very proud with their changed son, and soon the villagers started to notice Suma’s changed behavior. Everyone slowly forgave Suma and accepted him.
